items.title: City Housing Projects Call For Environmental Help
items.abstract: Housing project residents say the city encouraged them to “go green,” but did little to help them and in some circumstances, stood in their way.

items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: Ada Louise Huxtable, Champion of Livable Architecture, Dies at 91
items.abstract: Ms. Huxtable pioneered modern architectural criticism in The New York Times, celebrating buildings that respected human dignity and civic history.

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: New York City
items.abstract: New books include Gerard Koeppel’s “City on a Grid: How New York Became New York.”
keywords: City on a Grid: How New York Became New York (Book)
Fun City: John Lindsay, Joe Namath, and How Sports Saved New York in the 1960s (Book)
The Con Men: Hustling in New York City (Book)

items.title: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
items.abstract: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private project to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

items.title: As Cuomo Acts on Homeless Problem, New York City Blames State Cuts
items.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is only one player in addressing the issue in the city, but decisions his administration has made have left the city shouldering more of the burden.

items.title: The City Takes a Hit in Mr. Cuomo’s Budget
items.abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio must defend the city’s interests in any struggle over funds from the state budget.

items.title: Anger and Scrutiny Grow Over Poisoned Water in Michigan City
items.abstract: The state’s investigation into lead contamination of Flint’s drinking water follows the governor’s request that President Obama declare the problem a federal emergency.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: What’s Coming in New York Real Estate in 2019
items.abstract: An already soft market will get another 20,000 new apartments, making it an even stronger buyer’s and renter’s market.

items.title: Some Workers Need Jobs as Much as Builders Need Workers. Cities Connect Them.
items.abstract: In tight labor markets, developers and local leaders are using major projects to provide residents with careers in construction.

items.title: Michael Che Grew Up in New York City’s Projects. Now He’s Trying to Help Them.
items.abstract: The “Saturday Night Live” star has recruited a few friends to raise money for a group that assists public housing residents.

items.title: Nashville Finds Opportunity in the Hole a Bomber Left in the Heart of the City
items.abstract: Since the explosion last Christmas, the city has grappled with how rebuilding will fit into its larger ambitions of transforming downtown. The hope is to draw more than just tourists.

items.title: Put a Female Statue on a Vacant Pedestal? An Italian City Says Not So Fast.
items.abstract: In Padua, Italy, a proposal to include a female philosopher in a monument whose 78 sculptures are all men has spurred debate.

items.title: Noncitizens’ Right to Vote Becomes Law in New York City
items.abstract: Starting next year, 800,000 legal permanent residents will be eligible to vote in municipal elections.
keywords: Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)

items.title: Edward Kirkland, Who Helped Preserve Historic Chelsea, Dies at 96
items.abstract: He played a less public but powerful role in creating the High Line, Hudson River Park and landmark districts in the Manhattan neighborhood.

items.title: A Mayor and the Challenge of Making the City Safer
items.abstract: Eric Adams made public safety a campaign issue. Now, as mayor, he will be held accountable.
